Typedef Documentation

typedef struct _PSMove PSMove

Handle to a PS Move Controller.

Obtained via psmove_connect_by_id()

Enumeration Type Documentation

enum PSMove_Battery_Level

Battery charge level.

Charge level of the battery. Charging is indicated when the controller is connected via USB, or when the controller is sitting in the charging dock. In all other cases (Bluetooth, not in charging dock), the charge level is indicated.

Used by psmove_get_battery().

Enumerator:
Batt_MIN 

Battery is almost empty (< 20%)

Batt_20Percent 

Battery has at least 20% remaining.

Batt_40Percent 

Battery has at least 40% remaining.

Batt_60Percent 

Battery has at least 60% remaining.

Batt_80Percent 

Battery has at least 80% remaining.

Batt_MAX 

Battery is fully charged (not on charger)

Batt_CHARGING 

Battery is currently being charged.

Batt_CHARGING_DONE 

Battery is fully charged (on charger)

enum PSMove_Bool

Boolean type.

Use them instead of 0 and 1 to improve code readability.

Enumerator:
PSMove_False 

False, Failure, Disabled (depending on context)

PSMove_True 

True, Success, Enabled (depending on context)

enum PSMove_Button

Button flags.

The values of each button when pressed. The values returned by the button-related functions return an integer. You can use the logical-and operator (&) to check if a button is pressed (in case of psmove_get_buttons()) or if a button state has changed (in case of psmove_get_button_events()).

Used by psmove_get_buttons() and psmove_get_button_events().

Enumerator:
Btn_TRIANGLE 

Green triangle.

Btn_CIRCLE 

Red circle.

Btn_CROSS 

Blue cross.

Btn_SQUARE 

Pink square.

Btn_SELECT 

Select button, left side.

Btn_START 

Start button, right side.

Btn_MOVE 

Move button, big front button.

Btn_T 

Trigger, on the back.

Btn_PS 

PS button, front center.

enum PSMove_Connection_Type

Connection type for controllers.

Controllers can be connected via USB or via Bluetooth. The USB connection is required when you want to pair the controller and for saving the calibration blob. The Bluetooth connection is required when you want to read buttons and calibration values. LED and rumble settings can be done with both Bluetooth and USB.

Used by psmove_connection_type().

Enumerator:
Conn_Bluetooth 

The controller is connected via Bluetooth.

Conn_USB 

The controller is connected via USB.

Conn_Unknown 

Unknown connection type / other error.

enum PSMove_Frame

Frame of an input report.

Each input report sent by the PS Move Controller contains two readings for the accelerometer and the gyroscope. The first one is the older one, and the second one is the most recent one. If you need 120 Hz updates, you can process both frames for each update. If you only need the latest reading, use the second frame and ignore the first frame.

Used by psmove_get_accelerometer_frame() and psmove_get_gyroscope_frame().

Enumerator:
Frame_FirstHalf 

The older frame.

Frame_SecondHalf 

The most recent frame.

enum PSMove_RemoteConfig

Remote configuration options, for psmove_set_remote_config()

Enumerator:
PSMove_LocalAndRemote 

Use both local (hidapi) and remote (moved) devices.

PSMove_OnlyLocal 

Use only local (hidapi) devices, ignore remote devices.

PSMove_OnlyRemote 

Use only remote (moved) devices, ignore local devices.

enum PSMove_Update_Result

LED update result, returned by psmove_update_leds()

Enumerator:
Update_Failed 

Could not update LEDs.

Update_Success 

LEDs successfully updated.

Update_Ignored 

LEDs don't need updating, see psmove_set_rate_limiting()

Function Documentation

PSMove* psmove_connect ( )

Connect to the default PS Move controller.

This is a convenience function, having the same effect as:

psmove_connect_by_id(0)
Returns
A new PSMove handle, or NULL on error
PSMove* psmove_connect_by_id ( int  id)

Connect to a specific PS Move controller.

This will connect to a controller based on its index. The controllers available are usually:

  1. The locally-connected controllers (USB, Bluetooth)
  2. The remotely-connected controllers (exported via moved)

The order of controllers can be different on each application start, so use psmove_get_serial() to identify the controllers if more than one is connected, and you need some fixed ordering. The global ordering (first local controllers, then remote controllers) is fixed, and will be guaranteed by the library.

Parameters
idZero-based index of the controller to connect to (0 .. psmove_count_connected() - 1)
Returns
A new PSMove handle, or NULL on error
enum PSMove_Connection_Type psmove_connection_type ( PSMove *  move)

Get the connection type of a PS Move controller.

For now, controllers connected via USB can't use psmove_poll() and all related features (sensor and button reading, etc..). Because of this, you might want to check if the controllers are connected via Bluetooth before using psmove_poll() and friends.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
Returns
Conn_Bluetooth if the controller is connected via Bluetooth
Conn_USB if the controller is connected via USB
Conn_Unknown on error
int psmove_count_connected ( )

Get the number of available controllers.

Returns
Number of controllers available (USB + Bluetooth + Remote)
void psmove_disconnect ( PSMove *  move)

Disconnect from the PS Move and release resources.

This will disconnect from the controller and release any resources allocated for handling the controller. Please note that this does not disconnect the controller from the system (as the Bluetooth stack of the operating system usually keeps the HID connection alive), but will rather disconnect the application from the controller.

To really disconnect the controller from your computer, you can either press the PS button for ~ 10 seconds or use the Bluetooth application of your operating system to disconnect the controller.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle (which will be invalid after this call)
void psmove_dump_calibration ( PSMove *  move)

Dump the calibration information to stdout.

This is mostly useful for developers wanting to analyze the calibration data of a given PS Move controller for debugging or development purposes.

The current calibration information (if available) will be printed to stdout, including an interpretation of raw values where available.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
void psmove_enable_orientation ( PSMove *  move,
enum PSMove_Bool  enabled 
)

Enable or disable orientation tracking.

This will enable orientation tracking and update the internal orientation quaternion (which can be retrieved using psmove_get_orientation()) when psmove_poll() is called.

In addition to enabling the orientation tracking features, calibration data and an orientation algorithm (usually built-in) has to be used, too. You can use psmove_has_orientation() after enabling orientation tracking to check if orientation features can be used.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
enabledPSMove_True to enable orientation tracking, PSMove_False to disable
void psmove_get_accelerometer ( PSMove *  move,
int *  ax,
int *  ay,
int *  az 
)

Get the raw accelerometer reading from the PS Move.

This function reads the raw (uncalibrated) sensor values from the controller. To read calibrated sensor values, use psmove_get_accelerometer_frame().

You need to call psmove_poll() first to read new data from the controller.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
axPointer to store the raw X axis reading, or NULL
ayPointer to store the raw Y axis reading, or NULL
azPointer to store the raw Z axis reading, or NULL
void psmove_get_accelerometer_frame ( PSMove *  move,
enum PSMove_Frame  frame,
float *  ax,
float *  ay,
float *  az 
)

Get the calibrated accelerometer values (in g) from the controller.

Assuming that psmove_has_calibration() returns PSMove_True, this function will give you the calibrated accelerometer values in g. To get the raw accelerometer readings, use psmove_get_accelerometer().

Usage example:

if (psmove_poll(move)) {
float ay;
psmove_get_accelerometer_frame(move, Frame_SecondHalf,
NULL, &ay, NULL);
if (ay > 0.5) {
printf("Controller is pointing up.\n");
} else if (ay < -0.5) {
printf("Controller is pointing down.\n");
}
}

You need to call psmove_poll() first to read new data from the controller.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
frameFrame_FirstHalf or Frame_SecondHalf (see PSMove_Frame)
axPointer to store the X axis reading, or NULL
ayPointer to store the Y axis reading, or NULL
azPointer to store the Z axis reading, or NULL
enum PSMove_Battery_Level psmove_get_battery ( PSMove *  move)

Get the battery charge level of the controller.

This function retrieves the charge level of the controller or the charging state (if the controller is currently being charged).

See PSMove_Battery_Level for details on the result values.

You need to call psmove_poll() first to read new data from the controller.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
Returns
A PSMove_Battery_Level (Batt_CHARGING when charging)
void psmove_get_button_events ( PSMove *  move,
unsigned int *  pressed,
unsigned int *  released 
)

Get new button events since the last call to this fuction.

This is an advanced version of psmove_get_buttons() that takes care of tracking the previous button states and comparing the previous states with the current states to generate two bitfields, which is usually more suitable for event-driven applications:

  • pressed - all buttons that have been pressed since the last call
  • released - all buttons that have been released since the last call

Example usage:

if (psmove_poll(move)) {
unsigned int pressed, released;
psmove_get_button_events(move, &pressed, &released);
if (pressed & Btn_MOVE) {
printf("The Move button has been pressed now.\n");
} else if (released & Btn_MOVE) {
printf("The Move button has been released now.\n");
}
}

You need to call psmove_poll() first to read new data from the controller.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
pressedPointer to store a bitfield of new press events NULL
releasedPointer to store a bitfield of new release events NULL
unsigned int psmove_get_buttons ( PSMove *  move)

Get the current button states from the controller.

The status of the buttons is described as a bitfield, with a bit in the result being 1 when the corresponding PSMove_Button is pressed.

You need to call psmove_poll() first to read new data from the controller.

Example usage:

if (psmove_poll(move)) {
unsigned int buttons = psmove_get_buttons(move);
if (buttons & Btn_PS) {
printf("The PS button is currently pressed.\n");
}
}
Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
Returns
A bit field of PSMove_Button states
void psmove_get_gyroscope ( PSMove *  move,
int *  gx,
int *  gy,
int *  gz 
)

Get the raw gyroscope reading from the PS Move.

This function reads the raw (uncalibrated) sensor values from the controller. To read calibrated sensor values, use psmove_get_gyroscope_frame().

You need to call psmove_poll() first to read new data from the controller.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
gxPointer to store the raw X axis reading, or NULL
gyPointer to store the raw Y axis reading, or NULL
gzPointer to store the raw Z axis reading, or NULL
void psmove_get_gyroscope_frame ( PSMove *  move,
enum PSMove_Frame  frame,
float *  gx,
float *  gy,
float *  gz 
)

Get the calibrated gyroscope values (in rad/s) from the controller.

Assuming that psmove_has_calibration() returns PSMove_True, this function will give you the calibrated gyroscope values in rad/s. To get the raw gyroscope readings, use psmove_get_gyroscope().

Usage example:

if (psmove_poll(move)) {
float gz;
psmove_get_gyroscope_frame(move, Frame_SecondHalf,
NULL, NULL, &gz);
// Convert rad/s to RPM
gz = gz * 60 / (2*M_PI);
printf("Rotation: %.2f RPM\n", gz);
}

You need to call psmove_poll() first to read new data from the controller.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
frameFrame_FirstHalf or Frame_SecondHalf (see PSMove_Frame)
gxPointer to store the X axis reading, or NULL
gyPointer to store the Y axis reading, or NULL
gzPointer to store the Z axis reading, or NULL
void psmove_get_magnetometer ( PSMove *  move,
int *  mx,
int *  my,
int *  mz 
)

Get the raw magnetometer reading from the PS Move.

This function reads the raw sensor values from the controller, pointing to magnetic north.

The result value range is -2048..+2047. The magnetometer is located roughly below the glowing orb - you can glitch the values with a strong kitchen magnet by moving it around the bottom ring of the orb. You can detect if a magnet is nearby by checking if any two values stay at zero for several frames.

You need to call psmove_poll() first to read new data from the controller.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
mxPointer to store the raw X axis reading, or NULL
myPointer to store the raw Y axis reading, or NULL
mzPointer to store the raw Z axis reading, or NULL
int psmove_get_magnetometer_calibration_range ( PSMove *  move)

Return the raw magnetometer calibration range.

The magnetometer calibration is dynamic at runtime - this function returns the raw range of magnetometer calibration. The user should rotate the controller in all directions to find the response range of the controller (this will be dynamically adjusted).

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
Returns
The smallest raw sensor range difference of all three axes
void psmove_get_magnetometer_vector ( PSMove *  move,
float *  mx,
float *  my,
float *  mz 
)

Get the normalized magnetometer vector from the controller.

The normalized magnetometer vector is a three-axis vector where each component is in the range [-1,+1], including both endpoints. The range will be dynamically determined based on the highest (and lowest) value observed during runtime. To get the raw magnetometer readings, use psmove_get_magnetometer().

You need to call psmove_poll() first to read new data from the controller.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
mxPointer to store the X axis reading, or NULL
myPointer to store the Y axis reading, or NULL
mzPointer to store the Z axis reading, or NULL
void psmove_get_orientation ( PSMove *  move,
float *  w,
float *  x,
float *  y,
float *  z 
)

Get the current orientation as quaternion.

This will get the current 3D rotation of the PS Move controller as quaternion. You will have to call psmove_poll() regularly in order to have good quality orientation tracking.

In order for the orientation tracking to work, you have to enable tracking first using psmove_enable_orientation(). In addition to enabling tracking, an orientation algorithm has to be present, and calibration data has to be available. You can use psmove_has_orientation() to check if all preconditions are fulfilled to do orientation tracking.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
wA pointer to store the w part of the orientation quaternion
xA pointer to store the x part of the orientation quaternion
yA pointer to store the y part of the orientation quaternion
zA pointer to store the z part of the orientation quaternion
char* psmove_get_serial ( PSMove *  move)

Get the serial number (Bluetooth MAC address) of a controller.

The serial number is usually the Bluetooth MAC address of a PS Move controller. This can be used to identify different controllers when multiple controllers are connected, and is especially helpful if your application needs to identify controllers or guarantee a special ordering.

The resulting value has the format:

"aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff"
Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
Returns
The serial number of the controller. The caller must free() the result when it is not needed anymore.
int psmove_get_temperature ( PSMove *  move)

Get the current raw temperature reading of the controller.

This gets the raw sensor value of the internal temperature sensor.

Bug:
Right now, the value range of the temperature sensor is now known, so you have to experiment with the values yourself.

You need to call psmove_poll() first to read new data from the controller.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
Returns
The raw temperature sensor reading
unsigned char psmove_get_trigger ( PSMove *  move)

Get the value of the PS Move analog trigger.

Get the current value of the PS Move analog trigger. The trigger is also exposed as digital button using psmove_get_buttons() in combination with Btn_T.

Usage example:

// Control the red LED brightness via the trigger
while (1) {
if (psmove_poll()) {
unsigned char value = psmove_get_trigger(move);
psmove_set_leds(move, value, 0, 0);
psmove_update_leds(move);
}
}

You need to call psmove_poll() first to read new data from the controller.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
Returns
0 if the trigger is not pressed
1-254 when the trigger is partially pressed
255 if the trigger is fully pressed
enum PSMove_Bool psmove_has_calibration ( PSMove *  move)

Check if calibration is available on this controller.

For psmove_get_accelerometer_frame() and psmove_get_gyroscope_frame() to work, the calibration data has to be availble. This usually happens at pairing time via USB. The calibration files are stored in the PS Move API data directory (see psmove_util_get_data_dir()) and can be copied between machines (e.g. from the machine you do your pairing to the machine where you run the API on, which is especially important for mobile devices, where USB host mode might not be supported).

If no calibration is available, the two functions returning calibrated values will return uncalibrated values. Also, the orientation features will not work without calibration.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
Returns
PSMove_True if calibration is supported, PSMove_False otherwise
enum PSMove_Bool psmove_has_orientation ( PSMove *  move)

Check if orientation tracking is available for this controller.

The orientation tracking feature depends on the availability of an orientation tracking algorithm (usually built-in) and the calibration data availability (as determined by psmove_has_calibration()). In addition to that (because orientation tracking is somewhat computationally intensive, especially on embedded systems), you have to enable the orientation tracking manually via psmove_enable_orientation()).

If this function returns PSMove_False, the orientation features will not work - check for missing calibration data and make sure that you have called psmove_enable_orientation() first.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
Returns
PSMove_True if calibration is supported, PSMove_False otherwise
enum PSMove_Bool psmove_is_remote ( PSMove *  move)

Check if the controller is remote (moved) or local.

This can be used to determine to which machine the controller is connected to, and can be helpful in debugging, or if you need to handle remote controllers differently from local controllers.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
Returns
PSMove_False if the controller is connected locally
PSMove_True if the controller is connected remotely
enum PSMove_Bool psmove_pair ( PSMove *  move)

Pair a controller connected via USB with the computer.

This function assumes that psmove_connection_type() returns Conn_USB for the given controller. This will set the target Bluetooth host address of the controller to this computer's default Bluetooth adapter address. This function has been implemented and tested with the following operating systems and Bluetooth stacks:

  • Linux 2.6 (Bluez)
  • Mac OS X >= 10.6
  • Windows 7 (Microsoft Bluetooth stack)
Attention
On Windows, this function does not work with 3rd party stacks like Bluesoleil. Use psmove_pair_custom() and supply the Bluetooth host adapter address manually. It is recommended to only use the Microsoft Bluetooth stack for Windows with the PS Move API to avoid problems.

If your computer doesn't have USB host mode (e.g. because it is a mobile device), you can use psmove_pair_custom() on a different computer and specify the Bluetooth address of the mobile device instead. For most use cases, you can use the psmovepair command-line utility.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
Returns
PSMove_True if the pairing was successful
PSMove_False if the pairing failed
enum PSMove_Bool psmove_pair_custom ( PSMove *  move,
const char *  btaddr_string 
)

Pair a controller connected via USB to a specific address.

This function behaves the same as psmove_pair(), but allows you to specify a custom Bluetooth host address.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
btaddr_stringThe host address in the format "aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:ff"
Returns
PSMove_True if the pairing was successful
PSMove_False if the pairing failed
int psmove_poll ( PSMove *  move)

Read new sensor/button data from the controller.

For most sensor and button functions, you have to call this function to read new updates from the controller.

How to detect dropped frames:

int seq_old = 0;
while (1) {
int seq = psmove_poll(move);
if ((seq_old > 0) && ((seq_old % 16) != (seq - 1))) {
// dropped frames
}
seq_old = seq;
}

In practice, you usually use this function in a main loop and guard all your sensor/button updating functions with it:

while (1) {
if (psmove_poll(move)) {
unsigned int pressed, released;
psmove_get_button_events(move, &pressed, &released);
// process button events
}
// update the application state
// draw the current frame
}
Returns
a positive sequence number (1..16) if new data is available
0 if no (new) data is available or an error occurred
Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
void psmove_reinit ( )

Reinitialize the library.

Required for detecting new and removed controllers (at least on Mac OS X). Make sure to disconnect all controllers (using psmove_disconnect) before calling this, otherwise it won't work.

You do not need to call this function at application startup.

Bug:
It should be possible to auto-detect newly-connected controllers without having to rely on this function.
void psmove_reset_magnetometer_calibration ( PSMove *  move)

Reset the magnetometer calibration state.

This will reset the magnetometer calibration data, so they can be re-adjusted dynamically. Used by the calibration utility.

move A valid PSMove handle

void psmove_reset_orientation ( PSMove *  move)

Reset the current orientation quaternion.

This will set the current 3D rotation of the PS Move controller as quaternion. You can use this function to re-adjust the orientation of the controller when it points towards the camera.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
void psmove_save_magnetometer_calibration ( PSMove *  move)

Save the magnetometer calibration values.

This will save the magnetometer calibration data to persistent storage. If a calibration already exists, this will overwrite the old values.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
void psmove_set_leds ( PSMove *  move,
unsigned char  r,
unsigned char  g,
unsigned char  b 
)

Set the RGB LEDs on the PS Move controller.

This sets the RGB values of the LEDs on the Move controller. Usage examples:

psmove_set_leds(move, 255, 255, 255); // white
psmove_set_leds(move, 255, 0, 0); // red
psmove_set_leds(move, 0, 0, 0); // black (off)

This function will only update the library-internal state of the controller. To really update the LEDs (write the changes out to the controller), you have to call psmove_update_leds() after calling this function.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
rThe red value (0..255)
gThe green value (0..255)
bThe blue value (0..255)
void psmove_set_rate_limiting ( PSMove *  move,
enum PSMove_Bool  enabled 
)

Enable or disable LED update rate limiting.

If LED update rate limiting is enabled, psmove_update_leds() will make ignore extraneous updates (and return Update_Ignored) if the update rate is too high, or if the color hasn't changed and the timeout has not been hit.

By default, rate limiting is enabled.

Warning
If rate limiting is disabled, the read performance might be decreased, especially on Linux.
Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
enabledPSMove_True to enable rate limiting, PSMove_False to disable
void psmove_set_remote_config ( enum PSMove_RemoteConfig  config)

Enable or disable the usage of local or remote devices.

By default, both local (hidapi) and remote (moved) controllers will be used. If your application only wants to use locally-connected devices, and ignore any remote controllers, call this function with PSMove_OnlyLocal - to use only remotely-connected devices, use PSMove_OnlyRemote instead.

This function must be called before any other PS Move API functions are used, as it changes the behavior of counting and connecting to devices.

Parameters
configPSMove_LocalAndRemote, PSMove_OnlyLocal or PSMove_OnlyRemote
void psmove_set_rumble ( PSMove *  move,
unsigned char  rumble 
)

Set the rumble intensity of the PS Move controller.

This sets the rumble (vibration motor) intensity of the Move controller. Usage example:

psmove_set_rumble(move, 255); // strong rumble
psmove_set_rumble(move, 128); // medium rumble
psmove_set_rumble(move, 0); // rumble off

This function will only update the library-internal state of the controller. To really update the rumble intensity (write the changes out to the controller), you have to call psmove_update_leds() (the rumble value is sent together with the LED updates, that's why you have to call it even for rumble updates) after calling this function.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
rumbleThe rumble intensity (0..255)
enum PSMove_Update_Result psmove_update_leds ( PSMove *  move)

Send LED and rumble values to the controller.

This writes the LED and rumble changes to the controller. You have to call this function regularly, or the controller will switch off the LEDs and rumble automatically (after about 4-5 seconds). When rate limiting is enabled, you can just call this function in your main loop, and the LEDs will stay on properly (with extraneous updates being ignored to not flood the controller with updates).

When rate limiting (see psmove_set_rate_limiting()) is disabled, you have to make sure to not call this function not more often then e.g. every 80 ms to avoid flooding the controller with updates.

Parameters
moveA valid PSMove handle
Returns
Update_Success on success
Update_Ignored if the change was ignored (see psmove_set_rate_limiting())
Update_Failed (= 0) on error
const char* psmove_util_get_data_dir ( )

Get local save directory for settings.

The local save directory is a PS Move API-specific directory where the library and its components will store files such as calibration data, tracker state and configuration files.

Returns
The local save directory for settings. The returned value is reserved in static memory - it must not be freed!
int psmove_util_get_env_int ( const char *  name)

Get an integer from an environment variable.

Utility function used to get configuration from environment variables.

Parameters
nameThe name of the environment variable
Returns
The integer value of the environment variable, or -1 if the variable is not set or could not be parsed as integer.
char* psmove_util_get_env_string ( const char *  name)

Get a string from an environment variable.

Utility function used to get configuration from environment variables.

Parameters
nameThe name of the environment variable
Returns
The string value of the environment variable, or NULL if the variable is not set. The caller must free() the result when it is not needed anymore.
char* psmove_util_get_file_path ( const char *  filename)

Get a filename path in the local save directory.

This is a convenience function wrapping psmove_util_get_data_dir() and will give the absolute path of the given filename.

The data directory will be created in case it doesn't exist yet.

Parameters
filenameThe basename of the file (e.g. myfile.txt)
Returns
The absolute filename to the file. The caller must free() the result when it is not needed anymore.
On error, NULL is returned.
long psmove_util_get_ticks ( )

Get milliseconds since first library use.

This function is used throughout the library to take care of timing and measurement. It implements a cross-platform way of getting the current time, relative to library use.

Returns
Time (in ms) since first library use.
